<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_virt2phys:
```c
static int metal_virt2phys(void *addr, unsigned long *phys)
{
	off_t offset;
	uint64_t entry;
	int error;

	if (_metal.pagemap_fd < 0)
		return -EINVAL;

	offset = ((uintptr_t)addr >> _metal.page_shift) * sizeof(entry);
	error = pread(_metal.pagemap_fd, &entry, sizeof(entry), offset);
	if (error < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed pagemap pread (offset %llx) - %s\n",
			  (unsigned long long)offset, strerror(errno));
		return -errno;
	}

	/* Check page present and not swapped. */
	if ((entry >> 62) != 2) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "pagemap page not present, %llx -> %llx\n",
			  (unsigned long long)offset, (unsigned long long)entry);
		return -ENOENT;
	}

	*phys = (entry & ((1ULL << 54) - 1)) << _metal.page_shift;
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>

scenario: No violation in this macro itself. The macro expands to a conditional call to _metal.common.log_handler(level, metal_fmt(fmt), ...). It contains no calls to the <string.h> functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, strcpy, strlen, strerror is not used here). Therefore the fragment as shown does not violate Rule 21.17. Note: an indirect violation could occur if metal_fmt or the log_handler implementation uses string.h functions unsafely (e.g. overflowing a buffer), but that is outside the shown fragment and must be checked in those implementations.
